message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Functional programming and input/output
Paper Abstract: A common attraction to functional programming is the ease with which proofs can be given of program properties. A common disappointment with functional programming is the difficulty of expressing input/output (I/O) while at the same time being able to verify programs. Here, the author shows how a theory of functional programming can be smoothly extended to admit both an operational semantics for functional I/O and verification of programs engaged in I/O. He obtains, for the first time, operational semantics for the three most widely implemented I/O mechanisms for lazy languages, and proves that the three are equivalent in expressive power. He also develops semantics for a form of monadic I/O and verifies a simple programming example. These theories of functional I/O are based on an entirely operational theory of functional programming, developed using Abramsky's applicative bisimulation. Graduate students and researchers will gain much from reading this book.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about operational semantics:

## Definition

Operational semantics describes how a valid program is interpreted as sequences of computational steps, and these sequences constitute the meaning of the program.

## Key Characteristics

Operational semantics focuses on the run-time behavior of programs—what happens during the execution of instructions—and interprets the execution of a program as a series of steps, each involving the transition from one state to another.

In the context of functional programming, the final step in a terminating sequence returns the value of the program.

## History

The first use of the term "operational semantics" in its present meaning is attributed to Dana Scott.(no content)The concept of operational semantics was used for the first time in defining the semantics of Algol 68.

## Major Approaches

Gordon Plotkin introduced structural operational semantics, Matthias Felleisen and Robert Hieb introduced reduction semantics, and Gilles Kahn introduced natural semantics.(no content)Structural operational semantics (SOS, also called structured operational semantics or small-step semantics) was introduced by Gordon Plotkin as a logical means to define operational semantics.(no content)Thanks to its intuitive look and easy-to-follow structure, SOS has gained great popularity and has become a de facto standard in defining operational semantics.

## Related Approaches

Other approaches to providing formal semantics of programming languages include axiomatic semantics and denotational semantics.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Gordon Plotkin introduced structural operational semantics, Matthias Felleisen and Robert Hieb introduced reduction semantics, and Gilles Kahn introduced natural semantics.(no content)Structural operational semantics (SOS, also called structured operational semantics or small-step semantics) was introduced by Gordon Plotkin as a logical means to define operational semantics.(no content)Thanks to its intuitive look and easy-to-follow structure, SOS has gained great popularity and has become a de facto standard in defining operational semantics.

## Related Approaches

Other approaches to providing formal semantics of programming languages include axiomatic semantics and denotational semantics.

Smolka - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_A._Smolka"},{"title":"π-calculus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi-calculus"}]

## Bisimulation

In theoretical computer science, a bisimulation is a binary relation between state transition systems, associating systems that behave in the same way in that one system simulates the other and vice versa.(no content)Two systems are bisimilar if they match each other's moves, and in this sense, each of the systems cannot be distinguished from the other by an observer.

### Key Properties

The set of bisimulations is closed under union; therefore, the bisimilarity relation is the union of all bisimulations and the unique largest bisimulation.(no content)The largest bisimulation—bisimilarity—is an equivalence relation.

### Game-Theoretic Interpretation

Bisimulation can be thought of in terms of a game between two players: attacker and defender, where the system is a bisimulation if and only if there exists a winning strategy for the defender.

### Variants and Applications

There are several extensions of the basic concept:

- Probabilistic bisimulation is an extension of the concept of bisimulation for fully probabilistic transition systems first described by K.G. Larsen and A. Skou.
- A stutter bisimulation is a relationship between two transition systems where a stutter bisimulation allows transitions to be matched to finite path fragments.(no content)Many people use bisimulation to reason about when two programs give the same results, and also to reason about security protocols, using it as a proof technique to show that two programs are bisimilar.

Web search results for query: "Input output computing"

Links: [{"title":"Input/output - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input/output"},{"title":"IPO model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPO_model"},{"title":"Input (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Input device - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input_device"},{"title":"Programmed input–output - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Programmed_input–output"},{"title":"Input/Output Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input/Output_Control_System"},{"title":"Category:Input/output - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Input/output"},{"title":"Output device - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Output_(computing)"},{"title":"Input/Output Configuration Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input/Output_Configuration_Program"},{"title":"I/O virtualization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I/O_virtualization"}]

Here are the results from my web search on "Input output computing":

## Definition

In computing, input/output (I/O) is the communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, such as another computer system, peripherals, or a human operator.(no content)Inputs are the signals or data received by the system and outputs are the signals or data sent from it.

## Input and Output Devices

I/O devices are the pieces of hardware used by a human (or other system) to communicate with a computer. For instance, a keyboard or computer mouse is an input device for a computer, while monitors and printers are output devices.(no content)Devices for communication between computers, such as modems and network cards, typically perform both input and output operations.

## Input/Output Model

The input–process–output (IPO) model is a widely used approach in systems analysis and software engineering for describing the structure of an information processing program or other process.(no content)A computer program using the input-process-output model receives inputs from a user or other source, does some computations on the inputs, and returns the results of the computations.

## Data Transmission Methods

Programmed input–output (PIO) is a method of data transmission between a central processing unit (CPU) and a peripheral device.(no content)Each data item transfer is initiated by an instruction in the program, involving the CPU for every transaction. In contrast, in direct memory access (DMA) operations, the CPU is uninvolved in the data transfer.

Web search results for query: "Lazy evaluation"

Links: [{"title":"Lazy evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_evaluation"},{"title":"Talk:Lazy evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lazy_evaluation"},{"title":"Evaluation strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_strategy"},{"title":"Lazy initialization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_initialization"},{"title":"Functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_programming"},{"title":"Tak (function) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tak_(function)"},{"title":"Short-circuit evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-circuit_evaluation"},{"title":"Haskell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haskell"},{"title":"Evaluation (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Lazy systematic unit testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_systematic_unit_testing"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about lazy evaluation:

## Definition

Lazy evaluation, or call-by-need, is an evaluation strategy which delays the evaluation of an expression until its value is needed (non-strict evaluation) and which avoids repeated evaluations (by the use of sharing).

## Key Characteristics

Lazy evaluation does not evaluate function arguments unless their values are required to evaluate the function call itself. This contrasts with eager evaluation, sometimes known as strict evaluation, which is the evaluation strategy employed in most programming languages.

## Benefits

Lazy evaluation offers several advantages:

- The ability to define control flow (structures) as abstractions instead of primitives.
- The ability to define potentially infinite data structures.
- Delayed evaluation has the advantage of being able to create calculable infinite lists without infinite loops or size matters interfering in computation. The actual values are only computed when needed.
- Lazy evaluation is fundamental in big data frameworks such as Apache Spark, where computations on distributed datasets are delayed until results are explicitly needed, allowing for execution optimizations and reduction of unnecessary processing.

## Challenges

Lazy evaluation is difficult to combine with imperative features such as exception handling and input/output, because the order of operations becomes indeterminate.

## Languages

Lazy evaluation is used by default in several pure functional languages, including Miranda, Clean, and Haskell.

Links: [{"title":"Monad (functional programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monad_(functional_programming)"},{"title":"Monad (category theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monad_(category_theory)"},{"title":"Talk:Monad (functional programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Monad_(functional_programming)"},{"title":"Talk:Monad (functional programming)/Archive 1","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk%3AMonad_%28functional_programming%29%2FArchive_1?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Monadic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monadic"},{"title":"Philip Wadler - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Wadler"},{"title":"APL (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/APL_(programming_language)"},{"title":"Haskell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haskell_programming"},{"title":"List (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"Functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_systems_in_functional_programming_languages"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of monad programming:

## What is a Monad?

In functional programming, monads are a way to structure computations as a sequence of steps, where each step not only produces a value but also some extra information about the computation, such as a potential failure, non-determinism, or side effect.

## Core Components

A monad consists of three parts: A type constructor M that builds up a monadic type, a type converter often called unit or return that embeds an object in the monad, and a combinator typically called bind (represented with >>= or flatMap) that unwraps a monadic variable and inserts it into a monadic function.

## Practical Benefits

By reifying a specific kind of computation, a monad not only encapsulates the tedious details of that computational pattern, but it does so in a declarative way, improving the code's clarity.(no content)Programmers typically use bind to chain monadic functions into a sequence, which has led some to describe monads as "programmable semicolons".

## Common Uses

Monads offer a way to abstract certain types of computational patterns, including modeling of computations with mutable state and other side effects such as I/O in an imperative manner without losing purity.(no content)In functional programming, the maybe monad models partial computations, that is, computations that may fail.

## Language Support

At first, programming with monads was largely confined to Haskell and its derivatives, but as functional programming has influenced other paradigms, many languages have incorporated a monad pattern, with formulations now existing in Scheme, Perl, Python, Racket, Clojure, Scala, F#, and others.

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"Software verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification"},{"title":"Software verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Runtime verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runtime_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"Counterexample-guided abstraction refinement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterexample-guided_abstraction_refinement"},{"title":"Greg Nelson (computer scientist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Nelson_(computer_scientist)"},{"title":"E-Verify - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-Verify"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of program verification:

## Definition and Purpose

Software verification is a discipline of software engineering, programming languages, and theory of computation whose goal is to assure that software satisfies the expected requirements.(no content)Software verification asks the question, "Are we building the product right?"; that is, does the software conform to its specifications?

## Types of Verification

Program verification encompasses two main approaches:

- **Static Verification**: Static verification is the process of checking that software meets requirements by inspecting the code before it runs.

- **Dynamic Verification**: Dynamic verification is performed during the execution of software, and dynamically checks its behavior; it is commonly known as the Test phase.

## Formal Verification

Formal verification of software programs involves proving that a program satisfies a formal specification of its behavior.(no content)Formal verification can be helpful in proving the correctness of systems such as: cryptographic protocols, combinational circuits, digital circuits with internal memory, and software expressed as source code in a programming language.(no content)Subareas of formal verification include deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods.

## Key Techniques

- **Model Checking**: Model checking or property checking is a method for checking whether a finite-state model of a system meets a given specification (also known as correctness).

- **Runtime Verification**: Runtime verification is a computing system analysis and execution approach based on extracting information from a running system and using it to detect and possibly react to observed behaviors satisfying or violating certain properties.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_programming"},{"title":"Total functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_functional_programming"},{"title":"Purely functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purely_functional_programming"},{"title":"List of functional programming topics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_functional_programming_topics"},{"title":"Comparison of functional programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_functional_programming_languages"},{"title":"International Conference on Functional Programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Functional_Programming"},{"title":"Algebraic Logic Functional programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_Logic_Functional_programming_language"},{"title":"Functor (functional programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functor_(functional_programming)"},{"title":"Monad (functional programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monad_(functional_programming)"},{"title":"Talk:Functor (functional programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Functor_(functional_programming)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about functional programming:

## Overview

Functional programming is a programming paradigm where programs are constructed by applying and composing functions.(no content)It is a declarative programming paradigm in which function definitions are trees of expressions that map values to other values, rather than a sequence of imperative statements which update the running state of the program.

## Key Characteristics

In functional programming, functions are treated as first-class citizens, meaning that they can be bound to names (including local identifiers), passed as arguments, and returned from other functions, just as any other data type can.(no content)Functional programming is sometimes treated as synonymous with purely functional programming, a subset of functional programming that treats all functions as deterministic mathematical functions, or pure functions.(no content)When a pure function is called with some given arguments, it will always return the same result, and cannot be affected by any mutable state or other side effects.

## Benefits

Proponents of purely functional programming claim that by restricting side effects, programs can have fewer bugs, be easier to debug and test, and be more suited to formal verification.

## Historical Background

Functional programming has its roots in academia, evolving from the lambda calculus, a formal system of computation based only on functions.(no content)The first high-level functional programming language, Lisp, was developed in the late 1950s for the IBM 700/7000 series of scientific computers by John McCarthy while at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

## Popular Languages

Functional programming has historically been less popular than imperative programming, but many functional languages are seeing use today in industry and education, including Common Lisp, Scheme, Clojure, Wolfram Language, Racket, Erlang, Elixir, OCaml, Haskell, and F#. Additionally, many other programming languages support programming in a functional style or have implemented features from functional programming, such as C++ (since C++11), C#, Kotlin, Perl, PHP, Python, Go, Rust, Raku, Scala, and Java (since Java 8).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Additionally, many other programming languages support programming in a functional style or have implemented features from functional programming, such as C++ (since C++11), C#, Kotlin, Perl, PHP, Python, Go, Rust, Raku, Scala, and Java (since Java 8).

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about functional programming:

## Overview

Functional programming is a programming paradigm where programs are constructed by applying and composing functions.(no content)It is a declarative programming paradigm in which function definitions are trees of expressions that map values to other values, rather than a sequence of imperative statements which update the running state of the program.

## Key Characteristics

In functional programming, functions are treated as first-class citizens, meaning that they can be bound to names (including local identifiers), passed as arguments, and returned from other functions, just as any other data type can.(no content)Functional programming is sometimes treated as synonymous with purely functional programming, a subset of functional programming that treats all functions as deterministic mathematical functions, or pure functions.(no content)When a pure function is called with some given arguments, it will always return the same result, and cannot be affected by any mutable state or other side effects.

## Benefits

Proponents of purely functional programming claim that by restricting side effects, programs can have fewer bugs, be easier to debug and test, and be more suited to formal verification.

## Historical Background

Functional programming has its roots in academia, evolving from the lambda calculus, a formal system of computation based only on functions.(no content)The first high-level functional programming language, Lisp, was developed in the late 1950s for the IBM 700/7000 series of scientific computers by John McCarthy while at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

## Popular Languages

Functional programming has historically been less popular than imperative programming, but many functional languages are seeing use today in industry and education, including Common Lisp, Scheme, Clojure, Wolfram Language, Racket, Erlang, Elixir, OCaml, Haskell, and F#. Additionally, many other programming languages support programming in a functional style or have implemented features from functional programming, such as C++ (since C++11), C#, Kotlin, Perl, PHP, Python, Go, Rust, Raku, Scala, and Java (since Java 8).

## Primary Article: Input/Output

In computing, input/output (I/O) is the communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, such as another computer system, peripherals, or a human operator.(no content)Inputs are the signals or data received by the system and outputs are the signals or data sent from it.(no content)A keyboard or computer mouse is an input device for a computer, while monitors and printers are output devices. However, the designation of a device as either input or output depends on perspective, as mice and keyboards take physical movements that the human user outputs and convert them into input signals that a computer can understand.

## Related Wikipedia Articles

The search also returned several other I/O-related articles:

- **Input–output model**: In economics, an input–output model is a quantitative economic model that represents the interdependencies between different sectors of a national economy or different regional economies.

- **General-purpose input/output (GPIO)**: A GPIO is an uncommitted digital signal pin on an integrated circuit or electronic circuit that can be used as an input or output, or both, and is controllable by software.

- **Input and Output Devices**: Separate articles cover input devices like keyboards and mice, and output devices like monitors and printers.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about I/O (input/output) in computers:

## Definition

In computing, input/output (I/O) is the communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, such as another computer system, peripherals, or a human operator.

## Basic Concepts

Inputs are the signals or data received by the system and outputs are the signals or data sent from it.(no content)The term can also be used as part of an action; to "perform I/O" is to perform an input or output operation.

## I/O Devices

I/O devices are the pieces of hardware used by a human (or other system) to communicate with a computer. For instance, a keyboard or computer mouse is an input device for a computer, while monitors and printers are output devices.(no content)Devices for communication between computers, such as modems and network cards, typically perform both input and output operations.

## I/O Methods

There are several approaches to implementing I/O in computer systems:

- Memory-mapped I/O uses the same address space to address both main memory and I/O devices. The memory and registers of the I/O devices are mapped to address values, so a memory address may refer to either a portion of physical RAM or to memory and registers of the I/O device.

- Asynchronous I/O is a form of input/output processing that permits other processing to continue before the I/O operation has finished.

I found comprehensive information about I/O (Input/Output) computing basics from Wikipedia. Here are the key points:

## Definition

In computing, input/output (I/O) is the communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, such as another computer system, peripherals, or a human operator.

## Inputs and Outputs

Inputs are the signals or data received by the system and outputs are the signals or data sent from it.

## I/O Devices

I/O devices are the pieces of hardware used by a human (or other system) to communicate with a computer. For instance, a keyboard or computer mouse is an input device for a computer, while monitors and printers are output devices.(no content)Devices for communication between computers, such as modems and network cards, typically perform both input and output operations.

## Types of I/O Approaches

There are several different approaches to handling I/O:

- **Memory-mapped I/O**: Memory-mapped I/O uses the same address space to address both main memory and I/O devices. The memory and registers of the I/O devices are mapped to address values.

- **Asynchronous I/O**: Asynchronous I/O is a form of input/output processing that permits other processing to continue before the I/O operation has finished.

- **I/O Scheduling**: Input/output scheduling is the method that computer operating systems use to decide in which order I/O operations will be submitted to storage volumes.

Links: [{"title":"Input/output - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input/output"},{"title":"I/O bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I/O_bound"},{"title":"Channel I/O - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Channel_I/O"},{"title":"Asynchronous I/O - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_I/O"},{"title":"Memory-mapped I/O and port-mapped I/O - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory-mapped_I/O_and_port-mapped_I/O"},{"title":"Io - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Io"},{"title":"Input/Output Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input/Output_Control_System"},{"title":"Glossary of computer science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_computer_science"},{"title":"I/O virtualization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I/O_virtualization"},{"title":"I/O scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I/O_scheduling"}]

I found comprehensive information about I/O (Input/Output) computing basics from Wikipedia. Here are the key points:

## Definition

In computing, input/output (I/O) is the communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, such as another computer system, peripherals, or a human operator.

## Inputs and Outputs

Inputs are the signals or data received by the system and outputs are the signals or data sent from it.

## I/O Devices

I/O devices are the pieces of hardware used by a human (or other system) to communicate with a computer. For instance, a keyboard or computer mouse is an input device for a computer, while monitors and printers are output devices.(no content)Devices for communication between computers, such as modems and network cards, typically perform both input and output operations.

## Types of I/O Approaches

There are several different approaches to handling I/O:

- **Memory-mapped I/O**: Memory-mapped I/O uses the same address space to address both main memory and I/O devices. The memory and registers of the I/O devices are mapped to address values.

- **Asynchronous I/O**: Asynchronous I/O is a form of input/output processing that permits other processing to continue before the I/O operation has finished.

- **I/O Scheduling**: Input/output scheduling is the method that computer operating systems use to decide in which order I/O operations will be submitted to storage volumes.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

3. **Operational semantics** (proposes) - Novel operational semantics for functional I/O
4. **Bisimulation** (uses) - Applicative bisimulation provides the theoretical foundation
5. **Lazy evaluation** (uses) - The paper addresses I/O for lazy languages
6. **Monad (functional programming)** (proposes) - Develops semantics for monadic I/O
7. **Formal verification** (proposes) - Proves program properties and verifies I/O operations
